mnemonic: TER sounds like 'TEAR' - to HAVE something you won't TEAR apart
grammar_notes: Essential irregular verb. Used for possession age physical states.
cultural_note: TER replaces 'to be' for age/hunger/thirst - 'tenho 20 anos' not 'sou 20 anos'!
example2_en: I want to have a dog.

mnemonic: TENHO - TEN + YO (Spanish influence). I have TEN of them YO!
grammar_notes: Irregular first person. The 'nh' sounds like Spanish 'ñ'.
cultural_note: 'Tenho' starts many daily expressions: tenho fome sede sono pressa...
tip: Irregular - note the 'nh' sound like Spanish ñ

mnemonic: TU TENS - informal YOU TENS (have ten things!)
grammar_notes: Second person singular informal. Note 's' ending marks 'tu'.
cultural_note: In the North (Porto) 'tu' is very common. Use 'você' in Lisbon until invited.

mnemonic: VOCÊ TEM - formal YOU 'TEM' (same as he/she)
grammar_notes: Formal 'you'. Same conjugation as ele/ela tem.
cultural_note: In business use 'o senhor tem' for extra formality.

mnemonic: ELE TEM - HE has TEM (ten) things!
cultural_note: 'Ele tem razão' (he's right - literally 'has reason') is very common.

mnemonic: ELA TEM - SHE has same as HE - TEM!
grammar_notes: Third person feminine singular. Same conjugation as ele/você.
cultural_note: 'Ela tem bom gosto' (she has good taste) is a nice compliment.

mnemonic: NÓS TEMOS - WE TEAM-OS (we team up and have!)
grammar_notes: First person plural. The '-mos' ending marks 'we' forms.
cultural_note: 'Temos de ir' (we have to go) uses ter for obligation.

mnemonic: ELES TÊM - THEY have (the ^ hat makes it plural!)
grammar_notes: Third person plural. Circumflex (^) distinguishes from singular 'tem'.
cultural_note: Written with ^ (têm) to distinguish from singular tem - sounds the same!
tip: Note the circumflex accent - same sound as tem

mnemonic: TENHO FOME - I HAVE FOAM-E (hunger foams up!)
grammar_notes: Literally 'I have hunger'. Portuguese uses ter for physical states.
cultural_note: In restaurants you might hear 'Tem fome?' (Are you hungry?) before ordering.
tip: Literally 'I have hunger' - Portuguese uses ter

mnemonic: TENHO SEDE - I HAVE 'SAID-E' (I said I need a drink!)
grammar_notes: Literally 'I have thirst'. Uses ter not estar.
cultural_note: 'Morro de sede!' (I'm dying of thirst!) is dramatic but common.
example1_pt: Tenho sede. Uma água por favor.

mnemonic: TENHO SONO - I HAVE SO-NO sleep (so no energy!)
grammar_notes: Literally 'I have sleep'. Another ter + noun expression.
cultural_note: Portuguese has many ter expressions: ter medo (be scared) ter razão (be right).
example1_en: I'm sleepy. I'm going to sleep.

mnemonic: TENHO ANOS - I HAVE years (collecting birthdays!)
grammar_notes: Portuguese expresses age with ter not ser. 'Tenho X anos' = I am X years old.
cultural_note: When asked 'Quantos anos tem?' reply 'Tenho [number] anos'.
tip: Age uses ter not ser - 'I have X years'
